Situation1: They participate in a national continuing education program to maintain licensure and expertise in the latest treatments.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: Tax documents are organized a month before the deadline, and a free vaccine clinic runs this weekend at the community center.
Story: I stared at the calendar, feeling the weight of two worlds pressing in. As a pharmacist, I’d registered months ago for the national continuing education program—an intensive weekend of seminars, the only way to keep my license and stay sharp on new treatments. My manager and colleagues expected me to bring back insights, and I knew my patients deserved the best care I could offer. But as a citizen, I felt another pull. The community center was hosting a free vaccine clinic this weekend, and volunteers were needed. I’d already organized my tax documents, ready to file early, but this was different. The city’s public health team was short-staffed, and neighbors were counting on people like me to help. I could almost hear my mother’s voice: “We all have a duty to our community.” The two roles clashed in my mind—professional growth versus civic responsibility. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations, torn between the pharmacist who must stay current and the citizen who must step up in a time of need.
